claim: The city of Bielefeld is in North Rhine-Westphalia.

supporting.text: Bielefeld is officially listed as a city in the administrative division of North Rhine-Westphalia by the German government.

attacks.text: Bielefeld is officially listed as a city in the administrative division of North Rhine-Westphalia by the German government.
Some conspiracy theories claim that Bielefeld does not actually exist, which would imply it cannot be in North Rhine-Westphalia.
Administrative divisions can change over time, and historical documents might not reflect current boundaries.
The German government's official records are widely recognized as accurate and up-to-date for administrative purposes.
The Bielefeld conspiracy is widely debunked and lacks credible evidence.

supporting.text: Geographically, Bielefeld is located in the northeastern part of North Rhine-Westphalia, as confirmed by maps and atlases.

attacks.text: Geographically, Bielefeld is located in the northeastern part of North Rhine-Westphalia, as confirmed by maps and atlases.
Some outdated maps may still incorrectly label Bielefeld as part of Lower Saxony due to historical administrative boundaries.
The exact borders of North Rhine-Westphalia have changed over time, creating potential confusion about Bielefeld's current administrative status.
Modern official government sources and GPS mapping systems consistently confirm Bielefeld's location in North Rhine-Westphalia.
There exists a conspiracy theory claiming Bielefeld doesn't exist at all, which would invalidate its location in any state.
The Bielefeld conspiracy theory has been thoroughly debunked by numerous verifiable sources and first-hand accounts.

supporting.text: The city's postal codes and administrative records are consistent with its location in North Rhine-Westphalia.

attacks.text: The city's postal codes and administrative records are consistent with its location in North Rhine-Westphalia.
Postal codes and administrative records can sometimes span across state borders, leading to potential misclassification.
Postal code boundaries are strictly defined within state borders in Germany, minimizing the risk of misclassification.
Historical administrative changes could have outdated the records, making them unreliable for current classification.
German administrative records are regularly updated to reflect current geopolitical boundaries.

supporting.text: Bielefeld is part of the Detmold region, which is one of the five governmental districts of North Rhine-Westphalia.

attacks.text: Bielefeld is part of the Detmold region, which is one of the five governmental districts of North Rhine-Westphalia.
The Detmold region was historically part of Westphalia, which is distinct from North Rhine-Westphalia in some administrative contexts.
Modern administrative boundaries clearly define the Detmold region as part of North Rhine-Westphalia, regardless of historical distinctions.
Some conspiracy theories claim Bielefeld doesn't actually exist, which would make its location irrelevant.
The Bielefeld conspiracy is a well-known joke and has no basis in reality or official records.

supporting.text: Historical records and census data confirm Bielefeld's inclusion in North Rhine-Westphalia since the state's formation in 1946.

attacks.text: Historical records and census data confirm Bielefeld's inclusion in North Rhine-Westphalia since the state's formation in 1946.
Some conspiracy theories claim Bielefeld does not exist, casting doubt on all records about its location.
Administrative boundaries have shifted over time; early records may not reflect current borders accurately.
The Bielefeld conspiracy is widely debunked, and the city's existence is verifiable through modern geospatial data.
Post-WWII German state boundaries were clearly documented by Allied authorities and have remained stable since.
